original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares close on a five session low after continuous gains and profit taking
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka shares were down at close on Wednesday on profit taking and selling interest after continuous gains in the past sessions due to assurances in debt restructuring,  an analyst said.

The main All Share Price Index was down 0.76 percent or 84.36 points to 10,958.08, this is the lowest the market has been since 20 July,  this is the third consecutive time the market closed lower, while S&P SL20 was down 0.99 percent or 31.61 points to 3,167.38.

Sri Lanka is seeing some selling interest in the Lanka IOC counter as the island nation has signed a long-term contract with China’s Sinopec group to be a petroleum distributor in the island, the President’s media office said on May 22.

Sri Lanka has issued Request for Proposal (RFP) for China’s state-run Sinopec and Singapore-based energy firm Vitol after evaluating seven bidders to build the country’s largest refinery with a minimum investment of $4 billion, the island nation’s Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera said.

The first shipment of fuel from China’s Sinopec will arrive in Sri Lanka in the first week of August with a maximum retail price for fuel also on the cards, State Minister of Power and Energy D V Chanaka said.
Sinopec, China’s state-owned petroleum corporation, is among three foreign players who have signed contracts to enter the Sri Lankan market.

The monopolism in the private fuel sector owned by Lanka IOC is diminishing due to more private sectors entering Sri Lanka’s fuel market, which has pushed negative pressures on the counter, moving the market on red.
The market generated a turnover of 1.5 billion rupees, this is the lowest revenue has been since June 27, while the yearly average stands at 1.7 billion rupees.

The market was continuously seeing gains on domestic debt optimization (DDO) since July 04, but there has been profit taking and selling interest in the banking sector over constant gains in the past sessions, bringing the market down.
Sri Lanka’s announced domestic debt restructuring plan has avoided adding to the “fragility” of the banking system, World bank Country Director Faris Hadad-Zervos said.
Sri Lanka kept banks, which have already been hit by bad loans and mark-to-market losses out of re-structuring plan.
Losers during trade were Sampath Bank, Hatton National Bank and Cargills.  (Colombo/July26/2023)
